result.execSummary:
This case has not been concluded. Unless a judgment of conviction is entered, the defendant is presumed innocent of all charges.

Notice to employers: It may be a violation of state law to discriminate against a job applicant because of an arrest or conviction record. Generally speaking, an employer may refuse to hire an applicant on the basis of a conviction only if the circumstances of the conviction substantially relate to the particular job. For more information, see Wisconsin Statute 111.335 and the Department of Workforce Development's publication, Arrest and Conviction Records under the Law.

Defendant's first appearance in Drug Treatment Court.  Court explains rules and outlines expectations of the defendant while in the program.  
Defendant is ordered to comply with the rules, expectations and instructions/orders or they will be subject to sanctions including placement on the weekly sanction list or immediate incarceration.

Defendant's first appearance in Drug Treatment Court. The Court will adjourn the explanation of rules and expectations until the next hearing.
with Elements of criminal offenses to which plea is being entered, filed by Atty. Galaviz

11:27 AM Defendant Melissa Martinez in court with attorney Pablo Galaviz.  Peter Michael Tempelis appeared for the State of Wisconsin.
Parties have reached an agreement.
Attorney Galaviz to refile the plea questionnaire and proposed Drug Treatment Court Agreement in this matter.
Court conducts plea colloquy.  Defendant enters a guilty plea to Count 1. Court accepts plea as, knowingly, intelligently and voluntarily made. Court withholds entry of judgment as the defendant has been accepted into DTC. Court approves the Waukesha County DTC Diversion Contract.  Cash bail from 21CF1473 to be transferred to this matter pending sentencing.
